message_1: Suppose there are 6 people at a party. Each pair of people either know each other or don't know each other. What is the minimum number of pairs of people that must know each other to guarantee there is a group of 3 people who all know each other, or a group of 3 people where no two of them know each other?
message_2:
Let's use the Pigeonhole Principle to solve this problem. Consider one person at the party, say person A. There are 5 other people at the party, so person A either knows at least 3 of them or doesn't know at least 3 of them.

Case 1: Person A knows at least 3 people.
If any of the 3 people that person A knows also know each other, then we have a group of 3 people who all know each other (including person A). If none of the 3 people know each other, then we have a group of 3 people where no two of them know each other.

Case 2: Person A doesn't know at least 3 people.
If any of the 3 people that person A doesn't know also don't know each other, then we have a group of 3 people where no two of them know each other (including person A). If all of the 3 people know each other, then we have a group of 3 people who all know each other.

In either case, we are guaranteed to have a group of 3 people who all know each other or a group of 3 people where no two of them know each other. Since there are 5 pairs of people involving person A, the minimum number of pairs of people that must know each other to guarantee this condition is 3.
